heading.title: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
DIVISION 3 OTHER POWERS OF COURT [ss 64–73] 1 of 2

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
[s 64] s 64 Amendment of documents generally (cf SCR Part 20, rules 1 and 4; DCR Part 17, rules 1 and 4)

leg:heading.title: Amendment of documents generally (cf SCR Part 20, rules 1 and 4; DCR Part 17, rules 1 and 4)

p.text: At any stage of proceedings, the court may order:
that any document in the proceedings be amended, or
that leave be granted to a party to amend any document in the proceedings.

Subject to section 58, all necessary amendments are to be made for the purpose of determining the real questions raised by or otherwise depending on the proceedings, correcting any defect or error in the proceedings and avoiding multiplicity of proceedings.

An order under this section may be made even if the amendment would have the effect of adding or substituting a cause of action that has arisen after the commencement of the proceedings but, in that case, the date of commencement of the proceedings, in relation to that cause of action, is, subject to section 65, taken to be the date on which the amendment is made.
If there has been a mistake in the name of a party, this section applies to the person intended to be made a party as if he or she were a party.
[subs (4) am Act 23 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 17 May 2006]
This section does not apply to the amendment of a judgment, order or certificate.
Legislation cited in [s 64.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 58, s 64(1), (2).

The terms of CPA s 64(1) , (2) reflect an historical and conceptual distinction between the court's power to order amendment and its discretion to grant leave to a party who applies to amend. The court's power to order amendment is mandated, subject to compliance with the “dictates of justice” (see CPA s 58 ), where the amendment is “necessary” to correct defects or errors, to determine the real questions raised, or to avoid multiplicity of proceedings. It is directed primarily to ensuring that the court documents (most typically the originating process and particulars) accurately reflect the substance of the matters that are really in dispute between the parties: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [14] , [27], [30], [93] and especially [96] and [97] (amendment and adjournment wrongly granted during trial).

level.toc-caption: [s 64.2] Amendments necessary to determine the real questions raised

heading.title: Amendments necessary to determine the real questions raised

p.text: The requirement to make all amendments necessary to determine the real questions raised, and to avoid a multiplicity of proceedings, applies to the matters that have become contentious in the current proceedings: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [14] and [71]. Amendment will rarely be “necessary” where the contention is already explicit in the pleadings. But the necessity may arise in relation to matters that are either implicit in the formally raised issues or whose substances is apparent from the conduct of the proceedings, especially evidence that has been served or adduced. This may occur where the amendment reflects a matter that is reasonably to be inferred from the existing pleadings (Dwyer v O’Mullen (1887) 13 VLR 933 — as explained in Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [81] ; O’Keefe v Williams (1910) 11 CLR 171 at 205; BC1100040 ) or where it reflects the evidence filed in the proceedings: Tildesley v Harper (1878) 10 Ch D 393 (allegation traversed in affidavit rather than formal defence). It may also occur where the amendment reconciles the position of co-defendants about a matter in relation to which they have a common interest: Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 (patent suit — validity traversed only by one defendant — amendment allowed to permit other defendant the benefit of the invalidity finding in the proceedings).

Because the mandate to allow “necessary” amendments is confined in this way, the additional limitation that the power is “subject to section 58” may in fact have little scope for practical application to amendments of this kind: see Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [72] .

level.toc-caption: [s 64.3] Amendments to avoid multiplicity of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 64.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(1), s 90.

heading.title: Amendments to avoid multiplicity of proceedings

p.text: The criterion of “necessity” does not apply to require leave for proposed amendments that would raise new issues. Those issues may give rise to a risk of subsequent proceedings, and the prospect that they may is a relevant consideration in the exercise of the general discretion to permit amendment. However, the questions of necessity and discretion are different. And, in the exercise of the discretion to permit such an amendment, the moving party may be required to demonstrate the reality and the significance of the risk of other subsequent proceedings: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [34] , [87].
Legislation cited in [s 64.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56, 58.

Leave to amend may be sought for a wide variety of reasons, ranging from the mere correction of pleading errors to the alteration of parties and the addition (or alteration) of substantive causes of action and defences. Leave may also be sought at different stages of the proceedings. In all of these situations the court must have regard to both the overriding purpose of the CPA and UCPR and the dictates of justice: see CPA ss 56 and 58 . Discharge of the obligation requires consideration of the nature of the proposed amendment, and its consequences for the other parties and the expeditious conduct of the proceedings.

The proper result of that consideration must depend on the particular circumstances. But the obligation to comply with the overriding purpose permits recognition of a generality that leave to amend should be granted if the application is made in a timely manner and for a proper purpose: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [98] ; Clough v Frog (1974) 4 ALR 615 at 618; 48 ALJR 481; BC7400058 ; Horton v Jones (No 2) (1939) 39 SR (NSW) 305 at 309 ; Leotta v Public Transport Commission (NSW) (1976) 9 ALR 437; 50 ALJR 666 ; Commissioner for Railways v Bielewicz [1963] NSWR 482; [1963] SR (NSW) 466 ; Abela v Giew (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 344 ; Nominal Defendant v Cameron [1988] NSWJB 135 .

That generality is particularly apt where the proposed amendment merely reformulates a claim or defence within the scope of the existing factual issues. Amendments of this kind may well actually be “necessary” to determine the real issues in dispute: Antoniadis v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1998) 44 NSWLR 682 at 690–5 ; Commonwealth v McLean (1996) 41 NSWLR 389 at 396E–397D; BC9606432 .

Leave may even be given at a late stage of the proceedings. For example, leave may be granted on appeal where the amendment merely provides more specific allegations of a matter already raised on the existing pleadings: Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Phillips (NSWCA, Full Court, 27 August 1992, BC9201645) (specific pleading of a defence of inevitable accident)); or leave may be granted after the conclusions of the evidence where it merely brings formal pleadings into conformity with the evidence that has been adduced: Leotta v Public Transport Commission, above; National Australia Bank Ltd v Nobile (1988) 100 ALR 227 at 235; (1988) ASC ¶55-657 ; cf Ting v Blanche (1993) 118 ALR 543; (1993) ATPR ¶41-282; BC9305082 .

level.toc-caption: [s 64.10] Leave to amend — qualifications on the general principles

heading.title: Leave to amend — qualifications on the general principles

p.text: Four propositions have generally been regarded as defining the limits of the general discretion to grant leave to amend. These are:
the application for leave to amend must be made for a proper purpose;
the proposed amendment must be proper as to both substance and form — and not liable to be struck out;
the amendment must not cause undue prejudice to the other party; and
the amendment must be consistent with the “dictates of justice”:

Tildesley v Harper (1878) 10 Ch D 393 at 396 ; Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 at 710 , applied in Clough v Frog (1974) 4 ALR 615; 48 ALJR 481 ; Shannon v Lee Chun (1912) 15 CLR 257; Horton v Jones (No 2) (1939) 39 SR (NSW) 305 ; Longhurst-Saunders v Cooper (1956) 73 WN (NSW) 455 ; Ketteman v Hansel Properties Ltd [1987] 1 AC 189; [1988] 1 All ER 38 ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Mehta (1991) 23 NSWLR 84 at 106–7 .

It is an obvious requirement that amendments must comply with the rules in relation to form and must, at least when read with the original pleading, disclose an arguable cause of action or defence: Clough v Frog (1974) 4 ALR 615; 48 ALJR 481; BC7400058 . The amendment must also be sought bona fide for the purposes of the proceedings: Brooks v Wyatt (1994) 99 NTR 12 at 20 ; National Australia Bank Ltd v Nobile (1988) 100 ALR 227; (1988) ASC ¶55-657 .

level.toc-caption: [s 64.25] The interests of the administration of justice

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 64.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(1), s 57, s 58(1).

heading.title: The interests of the administration of justice

p.text: Despite the element of primacy explicit in the CPA s 56 declaration of the “overriding purpose” of the CPA and UCPR, the “dictates of justice” obligation imposed by CPA s 58(1) , 58(2)(a) requires fundamental weight to be given to the potentially competing considerations of justice between the parties (CPA s 56(1) and the efficiency of judicial administration (CPA s 57 ): Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 at [46] . Both the obligation to order “necessary” amendments, and the discretion to grant leave to amend, are subject to the “dictates of justice”. Consequently, in neither case is the matter to be determined solely by regard to the interests of the parties. Courts must take into account the court lists and the general desirability of efficiency in the conduct of the litigation: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [24], [92]–[97] ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 383–4; 104 ALR 165 at 169–70 per Pincus J; In the Marriage of Tichy (1991) 15 Fam LR 65 at 67; (1991) FLC ¶92-259; 104 FLR 442 ; and see also [34.4.3] ; GSA Industries Pty Ltd v NT Gas Ltd (1990) 24 NSWLR 710 at 713, 716 and 717 ; Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 at 362, 365 ; Australian National Industries Ltd v Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) (1992) 26 NSWLR 411 at 421 per Kirby J and 430 per Samuels JA; 9 ACSR 309; BC200402171 . See also [s 58.5] and [s 58.10] .

Delay, especially where there has been a material (and especially an inadequately explained) failure to comply with the directions or procedures of the court may justify the refusal of leave: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [4], [51]–[54] and [106], ; Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 631; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 383–4 per Pincus J at 387 per Gummow J at 391 per French J; 104 ALR 165 at 169–70 at 173 at 176; State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487 at 493–5; 75 LGERA 327 at 333–5; BC9203134 per Gleeson CJ; Menzies v CRCI Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 118; BC200703794 .

Delay is potentially relevant to the exercise of the discretion for a reason additional to its direction implications for either judicial efficiency or questions of forensic prejudice to the opposing party. Where a party has had adequate opportunity to plead and prepare their case it may simply be inappropriate to permit a party to amend further: Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [94]–[96] . For example it is inappropriate to allow a defendant, after a trial on the merits, to amend to raise a defence based upon the statute of limitations: Ketteman v Hansel Properties Ltd [1987] 1 AC 189; [1988] 1 All ER 38; [1987] 2 WLR 312 ; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Mehta (1991) 23 NSWLR 84 at 107; (1991) ASC ¶56-053; (1991) ATPR ¶41-103 . See further [s 58.5] and [s 58.30] .

The discretion involved in evaluating the potentially competing considerations required by the “dictates of justice” obligation ultimately results in an impressionistic decision which, apart from the clearest cases, is not dictated by any particular consideration or combination of considerations. Whilst all relevant considerations must properly be taken into account, none are decisive. The court must consider, and accord primary significance to, the extent to which the interests of justice require that a party should be deprived of a judicial determination of the merits of the claim or defence: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 ; Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543; BC9605357 ; Evans v Bartlam [1937] AC 473 at 489; [1937] 2 All ER 646 at 656; 53 TLR 689 ; Byron v Southern Star Group Ltd (1995) 123 FLR 352; 13 ACLC 301 at 311; BC9504214 ; Davies v Pagett (1986) 10 FCR 226; 70 ALR 793 .
(The detailed considerations relevant to question of late amendment and procedural default are discussed, with illustrative examples, in [s 58.20] and [s 58.30] .)

level.toc-caption: [s 64.30] At any stage of any proceedings

heading.title: At any stage of any proceedings

p.text: Consistent with the width of the considerations discussed in the preceding annotations, “forensic diligence” is to be encouraged: Nowlan v Marson Transport Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 116; 34 MVR 495; [2001] NSWCA 346; BC200105900 . Nevertheless, the section expressly permits leave to amend being granted at any stage of the proceedings.
An amendment may, and generally will, be allowed if it is sought at an early stage in the proceedings: Middleton v O'Neill (1943) 43 SR (NSW) 178 at 185; 60 WN (NSW) 101 .

If the application is made during the course of the trial the application for leave will need to show that the amendment will not, in the particular circumstances, occasion undue prejudice: Duke Group Ltd (in liq) v Arthur Young (No 2) (1991) 55 SASR 24; 3 ACSR 759 . Depending upon the nature of the allegation sought to be raised in the proposed amendment, it may even be necessary for the applicant for leave to show that special circumstances exist: Bradford Third Equitable Benefit Building Society v Borders [1941] 2 All ER 205 (late allegation of fraud).

It will be a sufficient basis for refusing leave to amend if the other party either has deliberately framed its case in a particular way and may have conducted the case differently had the new matters been in issue (Burnham v City of Mordialloc [1956] VLR 239 ; Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 ), or has been deprived of an opportunity to adduce evidence on the relevant issues: FF Seeley Nominees Pty Ltd v El Ar Initiations (UK) Ltd (No 2) (1990) 55 SASR 314 at 315 .

It may also be a sufficient basis to refuse leave if the late application would require an adjournment of the proceedings. The potential to compensate the opposing parties with an effective order for costs is unlikely, on its own, to be a sufficient justification for granting leave to amend. The risk of an adjournment, at least the risk of a substantial one, may occasion a considerable, and inappropriate, procedural injustice to the opposing party as well as contradict the efficiency of the court: Ketteman v Hansel Properties Ltd [1987] 1 AC 189 at 220; [1988] 1 All ER 38; [1987] 2 WLR 312 ; Aon Risk Services Australia Ltd v Australian National University (2009) 258 ALR 14; 83 ALJR 951; [2009] HCA 27; BC200906905 at [94]–[96] .

An amendment may be allowed even after reasons for judgment have been given or on appeal: Classic Gourmet Sausages Pty Ltd v Leda Commercial Properties Pty Ltd (2000) 97 FCR 313; 171 ALR 17; [2000] FCA 389; BC200001390 at [81] , [84] (amendment on appeal to add the correct corporate plaintiff): Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 (amendment to reconcile with the defence of a successful co-defendant). A proper basis for granting leave in such a case will exist if the lateness of the application has been occasioned by the conduct of the opposing party: Londish v Gulf Pacific Pty Ltd (1993) 45 FCR 128; 117 ALR 361 at 372–5 ; although the granting of leave to amend at a late stage of the proceedings is not necessarily confined to such cases: National Australia Bank Ltd v Nobile (1988) 100 ALR 227 at 235; (1988) ASC ¶55-657 .

A party may not amend after the trial, or on appeal, to set up a case that was not put at the trial, if either the raising of the ground at the trial may have affected the evidence led, or if it is unlikely that the result would have been different: Water Board v Moustakas (1988) 180 CLR 491; 77 ALR 193; BC8802592 ; Federal Commissioner of Taxation v Brambles Holdings Ltd (1991) 28 FCR 451 at 454–6, 462–3; 99 ALR 523 at 529, 535 ; Federal Commissioner of Taxation v Suttons Motors (Chullora) Wholesale Pty Ltd (1985) 157 CLR 277 at 284; 59 ALR 688; BC8501092 .

level.toc-caption: [s 64.35] Effect of amendment — matters arising after commencement of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 64.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.17.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64(3), s 65.

heading.title: Effect of amendment — matters arising after commencement of proceedings

p.text: UCPR r 14.17 allows a party to plead matters that arose after the commencement of proceedings. Apart from the permissive provision contained in s 64(3) the reference to “matters” in that rule would not include a “cause of action”: Baldry v Jackson [1976] 2 NSWLR 415 . However, s 64(3) makes clear that a new cause of action may be added even where it has arisen after the proceedings were commenced: Zappia v Grant Baines Transport Pty Ltd (2010) 77 ACSR 273; [2010] NSWSC 98; BC20100778 at [48]–[55] (statutorily required consent provided after commencement of proceedings). But r 1(3A) also makes clear that such an amendment, unless made pursuant to CPA s 65 , will only take effect from the date that the amendment is made.
Legislation cited in [s 64.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64(3), ss 64(4), 65(3).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 19.2(4), rr 6.28.

Parties’ rights and liabilities are generally determined according to the state of the law at the time of the events giving rise to the cause of action. This general principle is subject to a number of qualifications.

The nature of the proceedings: The nature of a particular claim may require the court to consider the position of the parties at the time of judgment: Application des Gaz SA v Falks Veritas Ltd [1974] Ch 381 at 392, 399; [1974] 3 All ER 51; [1974] 3 WLR 235 ; Turner v GIO (NSW) [1960] 61 SR (NSW) 1. This is the general position in relation to the assessment of damages. It also applies to claims for injunctive relief.

Judicial precedent: Judicial decisions must be made in accordance with the current state of any binding authority. Apprehended changes to existing authority may not provide a sufficient basis for adjournment of proceedings: see [s 66.15] . Changes to existing authority that occur after trial, in relation to points that were not raised at the trial, may not be raised on an appeal: [51.53.105] .

Statutory changes: Statutory provisions are generally applied without regard to amendments made after the cause of action arose. Hutchinson v Jauncey [1950] 1 KB 574; [1950] 1 All ER 165 ; Wilson v Dagnall [1972] 1 QB 509; [1972] 2 All ER 44 ; Application des Gaz SA v Falks Veritas Ltd [1974] Ch 381 at 392, 399; [1974] 3 All ER 51 . But subsequent statutory provisions may evidence an intention to apply to (i) accrued causes of action (ii) pending proceedings or (iii) any proceedings commenced after a nominated date. In all these instances the new statutory provisions must be applied: Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 230; BC200602058 at [53] (specific statutory provision declaring conduct no longer actionable).

Amendment & addition of parties: An amendment is regarded as taking effect from the date of the original pleading, rather than from the date that the amendment is actually made: Sneade v Wotherton Barytes & Lead Mining Company Ltd [1904] 1 KB 295 at 297 (amendment where original claim beyond jurisdiction); Air Link Pty Ltd v Paterson (No 2) (2003) 58 NSWLR 388; [2003] NSWCA 251; BC200305682 at [44]–[50] ; Baldry v Jackson [1976] 2 NSWLR 415 ; Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Larcos (1987) 13 NSWLR 286 ; Harris v Western Australian Exim Corp (1994) 56 FCR 1; 129 ALR 387; BC9407138 ; Roman Catholic Archbishop of Perth v AA to JC Inclusive (1995) 18 ACSR 333 at 348 . But if the amendment involves a cause of action that arose after the commencement of the proceedings, it will operate only from the time it is actually made: CPA s 64(3) . If an amendment adds a party to the proceedings it will operate only from the time it takes effect to join the new party: UCPR rr 6.28 and r 19.2(4) : Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 230; BC200602058 at [47] . But if the amendment merely corrects a mistake in the name of a party, the amendment will take effect from the commencement of the proceedings: see CPA ss 64(4) and 65(3) ; East West Airlines Ltd v Turner [2010] NSWCA 53; BC201001873 (mistake in name of party — significance of “as if” in CPA s 64(4) — amendment to take effect from date of filing of statement of claim).

The court has a discretion to impose terms on the grant of leave to amend. The discretion permits orders to be made that will minimise the procedural prejudice occasioned to the other parties by the amendment. The terms most commonly imposed relate to costs and adjournment. As to costs, the amending party must usually pay the costs of the application for leave to amend — unless, perhaps, the application for leave to amend has been unreasonably opposed, and then the opponent may be ordered to pay the costs of the application: Public Trustee v Nash (1921) 38 WN (NSW) 142 . The costs order will usually include costs occasioned by the amendment, such as those thrown away: Stewart v North Metropolitan Tramways Co (1886) 16 QBD 556 ; Andromeda Handelsaktieselskab v Holme (1923) 130 LT 329. As to adjournment, where the amendment raises a matter that necessitates an adjournment of the proceedings, the amending party will generally also be required to pay the costs of and thrown away by the adjournment: Balta v Sew ‘n’ Save Pty Ltd (No 1) (1980) 28 SASR 385 at 388 . But the court's power to impose terms is not limited to costs and adjournment. Terms may be imposed as to compliance with a procedural timetable for the preparation of the proceedings, or as to the factual matters to be raised in the evidence, or as to the date that the amendment takes effect: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Larcos (1987) 13 NSWLR 286 (relating to the time of the conferral of Trade Practices jurisdiction on state courts); Lipton's Cash Registers and Business Equipment Ltd v Hugin (GB) Ltd [1982] 1 All ER 595 .

The power to amend pleadings includes the power to amend particulars. If the particulars are contained in a document filed in the proceedings the application is governed by the same considerations as those that apply to the amendment of the substantive parts of the pleadings. Where particulars are given separately from the pleadings there is a view that they may only be amended by leave, although most of the cases are patent cases and there may be debate as to whether they are of general application: Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 ; Woolley v Broad [1892] 2 QB 317 . In any event, leave to amend particulars will usually be granted where the amendment is in accordance with the substance of the existing pleadings: Clarapede and Co v Commercial Union Assn (1883) 32 WR 262 ; and especially where the amendment sought is in accordance with evidence that has actually been given: Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658; 44 ALR 117; BC8200139 ; Mummery v Irvings Pty Ltd (1956) 96 CLR 99; [1956] ALR 795 ; Leotta v Public Transport Commission (NSW) (1976) 9 ALR 437 at 446; 50 ALJR 666 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 65] s 65 Amendment of originating process after expiry of limitation period (cf SCR Part 20, rule 4; DCR Part 17, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Amendment of originating process after expiry of limitation period (cf SCR Part 20, rule 4; DCR Part 17, rule 4)

p.text: This section applies to any proceedings commenced before the expiration of any relevant limitation period for the commencement of the proceedings.

At any time after the expiration of the relevant limitation period, the plaintiff in any such proceedings may, with the leave of the court under section 64(1)(b) , amend the originating process so as:
to enable the plaintiff to maintain the proceedings in a capacity in which he or she has, since the proceedings were commenced, become entitled to bring and maintain the proceedings, or

to correct a mistake in the name of a party to the proceedings, whether or not the effect of the amendment is to substitute a new party, being a mistake that, in the court’s opinion, is neither misleading nor such as to cause reasonable doubt as to the identity of the person intended to be made a party, or

to add or substitute a new cause of action, together with a claim for relief on the new cause of action, being a new cause of action that, in the court’s opinion, arises from the same (or substantially the same) facts as those giving rise to an existing cause of action and claim for relief set out in the originating process.
Unless the court otherwise orders, an amendment made under this section is taken to have had effect as from the date on which the proceedings were commenced.
This section does not limit the powers of the court under section 64 .
This section has effect despite anything to the contrary in the Limitation Act 1969.
In this section, originating process, in relation to any proceedings, includes any pleading subsequently filed in the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [s 65.5] Limitation period — amendment after expiry of local statutory

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 65.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64(1), Subsections 65(4), (5).

heading.title: Limitation period — amendment after expiry of local statutory

p.text: The present section confers a specific power to grant leave to amend to include a cause of action that would otherwise be barred under a relevant state limitation provision. Subsections 65(4) and (5) indicate that a more general discretionary power, though one still confined to limitations under state legislation, arises under CPA s 64(1) : Greater Lithgow City Council v Wolfenden [2007] NSWCA 180; BC200705646 (leave to amend statement of claim to add new cause of action after limitation period expired); Sagacious Procurement Ltd v Mayne Group Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1238; BC200510681 at [25], [26] (application to amend summons); Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 230; BC200602058 at [49]–[50] ; (application to amend statement of claim to introduce new, statute barred cause of action). These authorities follow the same approach as that previously taken in relation to the similarly worded provisions in the former Supreme Court and District Court rules: McGee v Yeomans [1977] 1 NSWLR 273 ; Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd (No 3) [2005] NSWSC 255; BC200501724 at [7]–[33] ; Bebonis v Angelos (2003) 56 NSWLR 127 at 138–9; [2003] NSWCA 13; BC200300211 (District Court rules); Minister administering the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 v San Sebastian Pty Ltd [1983] 2 NSWLR 268 at 314 ; Proctor v Jetway Aviation Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 166, overruling Chapple v Laming [1981] 2 NSWLR 765 and Proctor v Jetway Aviation Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 264; Chatsworth Investments Ltd v Cussins (Contractors) Ltd [1969] 1 All ER 143; [1969] 1 WLR 1 ; Sterman v Moore [1970] 1 QB 596 at 605 (amendment of a writ claiming damages in general terms); Brickfield Properties Ltd v Newton [1971] 3 All ER 328; [1971] 1 WLR 862 at 881 : see also Crafter v Webster (1980) 23 SASR 61; Mitchell v Harris Engineering Co Ltd [1967] 2 QB 703 at 720 ; Rodriguez v Parker [1967] 1 QB 116 ; Yew Bon Tew v Kenderaam Bas Mara [1983] 1 AC 553 . The effect of these statutory powers of amendment is to abrogate “the settled rule of practice” (known as the rule in Weldon v Neal (1887) 19 QBD 294 — see generally Renowden v McMullin (1970) 123 CLR 584; [1970] ALR 865; BC7000590 ), which precluded amendments being made after the expiry of a relevant limitation period. (The rule did not apply where the amendment either merely provided particulars of a previously pleaded cause of action: Black v City of South Melbourne [1965] ALR 698; (1964) 38 ALJR 309 ; or could fairly be regarded as merely another way of putting the same claim: Hall v National & General Insurance Co Ltd [1967] VR 355 ); Air Link Pty Ltd v Paterson (No 2) (2003) 58 NSWLR 388; [2003] NSWCA 251; BC200305682 at [57]–[58] ).

level.toc-caption: [s 65.7] Limitation period — amendment after expiry of Commonwealth statutory

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 65.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 64, 65.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 s 52, s 82, Sch 2.
(CTH) Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 s 59(2B).
(CTH) Federal Court Rules O 13 r 2.

heading.title: Limitation period — amendment after expiry of Commonwealth statutory

p.text: Where the relevant Commonwealth statutory provision operates to extinguish the underlying cause of action, and timely commencement is a pre-condition to the survival of the cause of action, no amendment can properly be allowed under CPA ss 64 and 65 unless proceedings on the cause of action were effectively commenced within the statutory period: Agtrack (NT) Pty Ltd v Hatfield (2005) 223 CLR 251; 218 ALR 677; [2005] HCA 38; BC200505627 ; Air Link Pty Ltd v Paterson (2005) 223 CLR 283; 218 ALR 700; [2005] HCA 39; BC200505628 (amendment after expiry of Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 (Cth) limitation); Timeny v British Airways plc (1991) 56 SASR 287 . Where the Commonwealth limitation provision does not expressly provide for the extinguishment of the cause of action the potential scope of the amendment power conferred by the sections is less clear. In Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Larcos (1987) 13 NSWLR 286 the court held that the power of amendment extended to permit a claim under Trade Practices Act 1974 s 52 (in relation to which jurisdiction was conferred by the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987) notwithstanding that the amendment was sought to be made after the expiry of the limitation period provided for in s 82 of that Act (see now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 s 82 and the Australian Consumer Law s 18 found in Sch 2 to the Competition and Consumer Act 2010). The decision of the Victorian Court of Appeal in PSL Industries Ltd v Simplot Australia Pty Ltd (2003) 7 VR 106; [2003] VSCA 7; BC200300607 is to the same effect. As is also the decision in Star v National Australia Bank (1999) 30 ACSR 583; 150 FLR 119; [1999] NSWSC 305; BC9901345 (amendment after Corporations Law s 588FE limitation). There are also similar decisions of the Federal Court in, for example, Rodgers v Cmr of Taxation (1998) 88 FCR 61; 158 ALR 220; BC9805404 (amendment after expiry of limitation period under the Corporations Law). (But the Federal Court decisions are distinguishable because of the specific provisions in Federal Court Act s 59(2B) and Federal Court Rules O 13 r 2 .) The decision in Larcos has been described as unsatisfactory and involving a “fiction”: Air Link Pty Ltd v Paterson (No 2) (2003) 58 NSWLR 388 at 420, 431; [2003] NSWCA 251; BC200305682 . It is arguably inconsistent with Timeny v British Airways plc (1991) 56 SASR 287 and with passages in the judgement of Toohey J in Wardley Australia Ltd v Western Australia (1992) 175 CLR 514 at 562; 109 ALR 247; BC9202700 . Nevertheless, it escaped critical comment in Agtrack (NT) Pty Ltd v Hatfield (2005) 223 CLR 251; 218 ALR 677; [2005] HCA 38; BC200505627 ; despite having been decided at the same time as the judgment that was the subject of the appeal in that case.

level.toc-caption: [s 65.10] Limitation period — amendment after expiry of foreign

heading.title: Limitation period — amendment after expiry of foreign

p.text: The Choice of Law (Limitation Periods) Act 1993 requires the court to regard laws relating to limitation periods in other States, in the Territories and in New Zealand as part of the substantive law of the other state. The same result would follow as a result of the application of the common law principles that govern common law causes of action: Regie National des Usines Renault SA v Zhang (2002) 210 CLR 491; 187 ALR 1; [2002] HCA 10; BC200200802 at [60], [75] and [76] (New Caledonia limitation law); Pfeiffer v Rogerson (2000) 203 CLR 503; 172 ALR 625; [2000] HCA 36; BC200003351 (Australian Capital Territory limitation law); not following McKain v RW Miller & Co (SA) Pty Ltd (1991) 174 CLR 1; 104 ALR 257; BC9102614 and Stevens v Head (1993) 176 CLR 433; 112 ALR 7; BC9303608 . However the power of amendment provided for in the present section would still be available to permit amendment if the proceedings had been commenced before the expiry of the limitation period provided for in a non NSW statute.

level.toc-caption: [s 65.15] Limitation period — amendment after expiry of contractual

heading.title: Limitation period — amendment after expiry of contractual

p.text: The power of amendment conferred by the present section extends to the case where a limitation period is imposed by the terms of the contract between the parties: Lloyds Steel Co (Aust) Pty Ltd v Jade Shipping SA (1985) 1 NSWLR 212 ; Marubeni Corp v Pearlstone Shipping Corp (The Puerto Acevedo) [1978] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 38.

level.toc-caption: [s 65.20] Date of amendment — addition of parties

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 65.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64(3), s 64(4), s 65(3).
(NSW) Workers Compensation Commission Rules 2006 19.1, rr 6.28.

heading.title: Date of amendment — addition of parties

p.text: Before the introduction of a provision such as CPA s 65(3) doubts were expressed as to whether an amendment that had the effect of adding a new defendant took effect from the joinder of that defendant, and left that defendant able to raise the expiration of a relevant limitation period: Fernance v Nominal Defendant (1989) 17 NSWLR 710 at 732–3 per Clarke JA; Air Link Pty Ltd v Paterson (No 2) (2003) 58 NSWLR 388; [2003] NSWCA 251; BC200305682 at [66] . UCPR rr 6.28 , 19.1 now make clear that where a person is ordered to be joined as a party to the proceedings the joinder takes effect on the date when the order is made, or such later date as the court may specify. However, it is implicit that a joinder authorised by an amendment falling within either CPA s 64(3) or s 65(3) relates back to the commencement of proceedings. Any other result would defeat the apparent intention of those provisions. In Fernance v Nominal Defendant (1989) 17 NSWLR 710 , for example, Gleeson CJ referred with approval to the judgment of McLelland J in Wenham v General Credits Ltd (SC(NSW), McLelland J, 16 December 1988, unreported, BC8801203). In that case it was suggested that the then equivalent to CPA s 64(4) (dealing with a mistake in the name of the party) required that such an amendment take effect from the commencement of the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [s 65.25] Date of amendment — dates other than commencement of the proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 65.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64, s 65.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010.

heading.title: Date of amendment — dates other than commencement of the proceedings

p.text: The court may determine the effective date for any amendment ordered under either CPA s 64 or s 65 : Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd (No 3) [2005] NSWSC 255; BC200501724 at [33] (the date of amendment may be imposed as a condition under CPA s 64); Air Link Pty Ltd v Paterson (No 2) (2003) 58 NSWLR 388; [2003] NSWCA 251; BC200305682 at [51] . If the amendment involves neither any limitation issue, nor a cause of action that arose after the commencement of the proceedings, there will usually be little reason to depart from the ordinary “relation back” principle: DJZ Constructions Pty Ltd v Pritchard (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 215; BC200902048 at [16] ; see further [s 64.40] . If the amendment involves a “post commencement” cause of action, it will usually be appropriate to allow the amendment to take effect from the date the cause of action arose. If the amendment involves a limitation issue it will normally be appropriate to allow the amendment to operate from the commencement of the proceedings.
Legislation cited in [s 65.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 65(2)(b).

A court may permit an amendment to correct a “mistake” in the name of a party if the mistake was neither misleading nor such as to cause reasonable doubt as to the identity of the “person intended to be made a party”: CPA s 65(2)(b) . If the mistake is of the relevant kind, amendment may be permitted irrespective of whether or not it was inadvertent or relevantly culpable: Bainbridge-Hawker v Minister of State for Trade & Customs (1958) 99 CLR 521; 32 ALJR 16; BC5800620 ; Harris v Raggatt [1965] VR 779 .

The most obvious occasion for the exercise of this amendment power is to correct minor errors in the description given to the intended party: Rodriguez v Parker [1967] 1 QB 116; [1966] 2 All ER 349; [1966] 3 WLR 546 (incorrect middle initial used); Allen Properties (Qld) Pty Ltd v Encino Holding Pty Ltd (1985) 10 ACLR 104; 3 ACLC 817; BC8500530 (minor spelling error); Rainbow Spray Irrigation Pty Ltd v Hoette [1963] NSWR 1440; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 142 (similarly named company); Mitchell v Harris Engineering Co Ltd [1967] 2 QB 703 (similarly named subsidiary company).

Conversely, the amendment power is not exercisable where the mistake relates to the basis of the cause of action, rather than the name of the party: The Aiolos [1983] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 25 (no mistake where an insurer sued in its own name when asserting a right of subrogation); Sibroll Pty Ltd v Mitch Properties [2007] NSWSC 579; (2007) 25 ACLC 862; BC200704400 (no mistake where liquidator deliberately, but incorrectly, commenced proceedings in the company name).

Between these two parameters the remedial amendment power covers cases not only of clerical error and misnomer, but also cases where mistake involves the identity of the party who satisfies a particular description: Bridge Shipping Pty Ltd v Grand Shipping SA (1991) 173 CLR 231; 103 ALR 607 at 627; BC9102619 (claim against ship owner — ship under charter — no amendment to substitute charterer); Evans Ltd v Charrington & Co Ltd [1983] 1 QB 810; [1983] 1 All ER 310 (proceedings commenced against principal rather than agent); Brandsma & Crockett Pty Ltd v Heindal Pty Ltd (2002) 26 WAR 323; [2002] WASCA 96; BC200201934 (similarly named related company); A & M Short Pty Ltd v Prestige Residential Marketing Pty Ltd (2005) 54 ACSR 760; 194 FLR 32; [2005] NSWSC 872; BC200506430 (error in name of party seeking to set aside a statutory demand); Greenwood v Papademetri [2007] NSWCA 221; BC200707297 (pleaded claim against owner and occupier — owner misdescribed — amendment allowed); contrast Sullivan v Van der Broek [1999] NSWSC 1177; BC9907914 (claim against some members of an unincorporated entity — no amendment to add others).

The section expressly allows an amendment substituting parties, and this includes the substitution of multiple parties for a single party: Greenwood v Papademetri [2007] NSWCA 221; BC200707297 at [108] ; McInnes v Wingecarribee Shire Council (1987) 10 NSWLR 660; (1987) 64 LGRA 137 ; Greentree v G D Searle and Company (NSWSC, McInerney J, 31 July 1992, unreported); Mitry v Business Australia Capital Finance Pty Ltd (in liq) [2010] NSWCA 360; BC201009834 (liquidator plaintiff — amendment to substitute the company in liquidation to comply with s 477(2) of the Corporations Act). There are differing views as to whether or not the amendment extends to permit the mere addition of a party. In Greenwood v Papademetri [2007] NSWCA 221; BC200707297 at [78]–[84] the Court of Appeal held that the reference to substitution in CPA s 65(2)(b) did not impose any restriction on the addition of a party. The Court of Appeal declined to follow the contrary decision of the Queensland Court of Appeal in relation to similarly worded rules. See also Preston v Nikolaidis [2010] NSWSC 427; BC201002883 at [6] (plaintiff granted leave to amend to formally add as a defendant a person who had previously treated as a party to the proceedings).
Legislation cited in [s 65.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 65(2)(a).

CPA s 65(2)(a) makes it clear that the rule extends to cover a case where the plaintiff's title to sue (for example as an administrator under a grant made after the issue of a statement of claim) altered after the commencement of proceedings: cf as to the former law: Bowler v John Mowlem & Co Ltd [1954] 3 All ER 556; [1954] 1 WLR 1445 and cases there cited. On the other hand, an amendment, under which a party claimed or was sued in a different capacity, may be disallowed: Hilton v Sutton Steam Laundry [1946] KB 65 ; Finnegan v Cementation Co Ltd [1953] 1 QB 688 ; cf McGee v Yeomans [1977] 1 NSWLR 273 .

level.toc-caption: [s 65.40] Arising out of the same (or substantially the same) facts

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 65.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64, s 65, s 65(2)(c), s 65(4).

heading.title: Arising out of the same (or substantially the same) facts

p.text: The saving provision in CPA s 65(4) makes it unnecessary to decide whether the power of amendment conferred by CPA s 65(2)(c) would otherwise be limited to proceedings where the existing pleadings disclose a cause of action (Bebonis v Angelos (2003) 56 NSWLR 127 at 138; 11 BPR 20,819; [2003] NSWCA 13; BC200300211 at [65]–[70]) or where there was similarity between material, as distinct from evidentiary, facts: New Cap Reinsurance v Reaseguros Alianza SA (2004) 186 FLR 175; [2004] NSWSC 787; BC200405609 at [89]–[93] . Under the present rule it will be appropriate to permit amendment if the claim based on the “new cause of action” arises out of substantially the same set of facts as those involved in the original claim: Chatsworth Investments Ltd v Cussins (Contractors) Ltd [1969] 1 All ER 143; [1969] 1 WLR 1 ; McGee v Yeomans [1977] 1 NSWLR 273 at 284–5 .

That question is to be answered as a matter of general impression rather than requiring precise similarity of factual circumstances. It is not necessary that all facts be material to each separate cause of action: Brickfield Properties Ltd v Newton [1971] 3 All ER 328 at 342; [1971] 1 WLR 862 at 880 (claim against architect — design allegations added to existing supervision claim). But it may be necessary to be satisfied that the form of the proposed amendment sufficiently discloses the nature and extent of the asserted similarity of factual circumstances: NSW v Radford [2010] NSWCA 276; BC201007998 (assault claim arising out of police arrest — proposed amendment to plead unspecified period of false imprisonment — insufficient similarity disclosed by proposed amendment).

For cases in which this subrule has been applied or considered see McGee v Yeomans [1977] 1 NSWLR 273 at 280 ; Proctor v Jetway Aviation Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 166 at 171, 174 ; Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Larcos (1987) 13 NSWLR 286 at 291–5 ; Barrier Pearls Pty Ltd v Security & General Insurance Co Ltd (SC(NSW), Greenwood M, No 16434/85, 16 April 1992, unreported, BC9201932) (marine insurance policy, original claim based on peril of the sea, amendment to raise construction defect not within s 65 but allowed under the general amendment power in s 64 ); Riverina Wines Pty Ltd v Tetra Pak Marketing Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1014; BC200707859 at [45] (leave granted to allow factually related contractual claims — leave refused in relation to new defect allegations concerning products destroyed since the commencement of proceedings).
Legislation cited in [s 65.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 56, 57, ss 58, ss 64, s 64(2), 65, s 65(2).

Any amendment requires leave of the court: see CPA ss 64 and 65 . The exercise of the discretion to grant or refuse leave must be in accordance with s 64(2) and follow the “dictates of justice”: CPA ss 58 , 57 and 56 . In principle those matters will require consideration of the nature and degree of any prejudice that the person sought to be added would suffer if the order were made: Greenwood v Papademetri [2007] NSWCA 221; BC200707297 at [35] . Where the proposed amendment satisfies the express criteria in CPA s 65(2) it probably is unlikely, given the nature of those criteria, that a person opposing the grant of leave will be able to demonstrate material prejudice. But the possibility of prejudice may arise, for example, where the amendment relies on the general power in CPA s 64 and where it will affect a person who was previously unaware of the proceedings or the likelihood of a claim being made against them. In instances of those kinds the court’s proper exercise of the discretion to grant leave will require consideration of a range of circumstances including the reasons for the amendment and the extent to which either grant or refusal of the amendment will cause relevant prejudice to the persons affected: see Itex Graphix Pty Ltd v Elliott (2002) 54 NSWLR 207; [2002] NSWCA 104; BC200201727 . See also [s 64.25] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 66] s 66 Adjournment of proceedings (cf Act No 11 1970, section 75)

leg:heading.title: Adjournment of proceedings (cf Act No 11 1970, section 75)

p.text: Subject to rules of court, the court may at any time and from time to time, by order, adjourn to a specified day any proceedings before it or any aspect of any such proceedings.

If a judicial officer is not available at the time appointed for the hearing of any proceedings, a registrar may adjourn, to a later time on the same day or to a later specified day, any matters listed for hearing by the judicial officer at the appointed time.
Legislation cited in [s 66.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA ss 56, CPA s 56(1), CPA s 58, s 66.

The court has both a specific statutory power under CPA s 66 , and an incidental power, to adjourn the hearing of any matter in appropriate circumstances: Hinckley & South Leicestershire Permanent Benefit Building Society v Freeman [1941] Ch 32; [1940] 4 All ER 212 ; Dick v Piller [1943] 1 KB 497; Priddle v Fisher & Sons [1968] 1 WLR 1478 . That discretionary power must be exercised in accordance with the overriding purpose described in CPA s 56(1) and in accordance with the dictates of justice described in CPA s 58 .

Those considerations require particular justification for refusing an adjournment application if the practical effect would be to terminate the proceedings adversely to the applicant for adjournment: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 628; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 ; Scott v Handley (1999) 58 ALD 373; [1999] FCA 404; BC9901689 (Full Federal Court); Frugtniet v State Bank of New South Wales [1999] NSWCA 458; BC9908056 . Similarly, the fact that a party has been taken by surprise about matters in issue, or has been confronted by unanticipated late evidence from another party, may provide a sufficient basis for adjournment: Biro v Lloyd [1964–5] NSWR 1059 at 1062; Collier Garland (Properties) Pty Ltd v Northern Transport Co Pty Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 1414 (unrepresented litigant); Scott v Handley (1999) 58 ALD 373; [1999] FCA 404; BC9901689 (late affidavit evidence served on unrepresented litigant). These examples have an additional force where the court is satisfied the adjournment would not substantially prejudice the other party: Spencer v VMD Packaging Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 118; BC200101956 at [58]–[64] (party and expert witness unavailable — tardy preparation by both parties — matter unlikely to be reached); Myers v Myers [1969] WAR 19 at 21 ; Wannal Pty Ltd v Jericho Nominees Pty Ltd (1985) 2 SR (WA) 297 ; Ahern v DCT (Qld) (1987) 76 ALR 137 (bankruptcy petition — pending appeal against judgment debt — considerations service).

Nevertheless the considerations in CPA ss 56 and 58 also justify the ordinary rule that where proceedings have been regularly fixed for hearing, with due notice to the affected parties, they should commence on the appointed date and continue until their completion. This ordinary rule is illustrated by refusal of adjournment applications:

occasioned by foreseeable difficulties in obtaining client instructions: Watson v Watson [1968] 2 NSWR 647; (1968) 70 SR (NSW) 203 at 206 (party’s suspected psychiatric illness — proposed medical examination);

occasioned by the late withdrawal of legal representatives, especially where the withdrawal relates to a fee dispute: Squire v Rogers (1979) 27 ALR 330 at 337–8; 39 FLR 106 at 113 (legal practitioners ceasing to act — fee dispute — application refused); Dawson (t/as Goodvibes Yachts) v DCT (1984) 56 ALR 367 at 369–70; 71 FLR 364 at 374 ; Kingsway Group Ltd v Belramoul [2009] NSWSC 345; BC200903445 at [11] (counsel briefed late — further adjournment refused — would not have done justice between the parties);

made for the purpose of obtaining additional evidence that should have been obtained earlier: Watson v Watson [1968] 2 NSWR 647; (1968) 70 SR (NSW) 203 at 206 (client’s uncertain capacity to instruct — withdrawal of legal representatives);

made for the purpose of investigating the availability of additional evidence: EG & H Nominees Pty Ltd v General Mutual Insurance Co Ltd (in liq) (1976) 50 ALJR 460 (further evidence anticipated — application refused); Kingsway Group Ltd v Belramoul [2009] NSWSC 345; BC200903445 at [12] (opportunity to explore further expert evidence suggested by newly appointed counsel — further adjournment refused);

where a party, or their legal representatives, has failed to make a conscientious effort to prepare for and participate in the preparation of the proceedings: Frugtniet v State Bank of New South Wales [1999] NSWCA 458; BC9908056 (repeated adjournment applications and conflicting court commitments); Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 628; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 (inadequately explained failure to retain counsel); Dekkan v Picciau [2008] NSWCA 18; BC200801127 (legal adviser’s lack of preparation); and
even where the parties themselves consented to the adjournment application: Sydney City Council v Ke-Su Investments Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 246 (amending legislation anticipated).

Despite the ordinary rule, but consistent with the basic purpose of the discretion, an adjournment application should be granted where it has a proper basis and refusal would result in serious prejudice: Walker v Walker [1967] 1 All ER 412; [1967] 1 WLR 327 (party employed out of the jurisdiction); Jordan v Smart [1961] NSWR 735 (civil jury trial — pending criminal proceedings arising out of the same issue); Deangrove Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [2002] FCA 1352; BC200208313 (non-compliance by both parties, late change of solicitors, preparation delayed by lack of funds, application made prior to hearing); Spencer v NSW Minister for Climate Change, Environment and Water [2010] NSWCA 75; BC201002114 (pending Hight Court decision — challenge to legislative basis for proceedings — adjournment to avoid the possibility of conflicting judgments).
Legislation cited in [s 66.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 66.

The specific statutory power conferred by CPA s 66 only extends to permit the adjournment of proceedings to a “specified day”. There is, in any event, a special objection to adjournments being made for an indefinite period because such adjournments may amount to a refusal to adjudicate, see, for example, Howard v Pacholli [1973] VR 833 ; Robertson v Chilia [1956] 3 All ER 651 ; Matheson v Matheson [1952] VLR 20. For example it would not ordinarily be proper to adjourn possession proceedings indefinitely merely for the purpose of allowing the mortgagor to pay the secured debt by instalments: Birmingham Citizens Permanent Building Society v Caunt [1962] Ch 883 and Mobil Oil Co Ltd v Rawlinson (1981) 43 P & CR 221.

level.toc-caption: [s 66.15] Change in law — adjournment where apprehended

heading.title: Change in law — adjournment where apprehended

p.text: An apprehended change in the law will generally not justify an adjournment, though much will depend on the particular matters in issue, and the circumstances in which the application is made: R v Whiteway [1961] VR 168 at 171 ; William Wren Canal Carrying Co v British Transport Commission [1956] 1 All ER 567 ; City of Sydney Council v Satara [2007] NSWCA 148; BC200704626 (trial judge should not have granted adjournment pending outcome in special leave application in the High Court raising a similar point in an unrelated matter but should have proceeded to apply the law as it stood; speculation of change in the law inappropriate; delay contrary to requirements of just, quick and cheap resolution of proceedings).

The existence of concurrent civil and criminal proceedings may justify adjournment of the civil proceedings: see McMahon-Winter v Larcombe [1978] 2 NSWLR 155 ; Jefferson Ltd v Bhetcha [1979] 2 All ER 1108; [1979] 1 WLR 898 ; Re Saltergate Insurance Co Ltd (in liq) and the Companies Act (1980) 4 ACLR 733 ; Ceasar v Sommer [1980] 2 NSWLR 929 ; Beecee Group Ltd v Barton (1980) 5 ACLR 33 and McMahon v Gould (1982) 7 ACLR 202; 1 ACLC 98 . As to the principles applicable in criminal proceedings, see McInnes v R (1979) 143 CLR 575; 27 ALR 499; BC7900106 . See also [s 67.25]

Where a party has failed to comply with interlocutory directions, particularly in relation to the content of pleadings or the filing of witness statements or affidavits, the court may refuse an application for adjournment: GSA Industries Pty Ltd v NT Gas Ltd (1990) 24 NSWLR 710 (hearing involving assessment of damages, further directions made for the provision of witness statements); State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487; 75 LGERA 327; BC9203134 (witness’ evidence ruled inadmissible because of non-compliance with directions); W Dazenko Structural and General Engineering Pty Ltd v Frazer Hrones & Co Ltd (NSWCA, Mahoney, Meagher and Handley JJA, 751 of 1988, 5 October 1990, unreported, BC9001911) (failure to comply with directions to file evidence, inability to participate effectively at hearing, absence of satisfactory and bona fide explanation). Even if there has been no actual failure to comply with directions, a party who has put itself in a position where it is not able to present its own case is not automatically entitled to an adjournment: Apex Pallet Hire Pty Ltd v Brambles Holdings Ltd (VSC, Full Court, 8 April 1988; unreported, BC8800750); Regal Life Insurance Ltd v Pacific Financial Resources Pty Ltd (VSC, Batt J, 2145 of 1992, 16 November 1994, unreported, BC9401301) (potential unavailability of witnesses, refusal of adjournment did not preclude meaningful participation at the hearing). If the party in default applies to be excused from the consequences of non-compliance, and the opposing party would thereby be entitled to an adjournment, that circumstance may justify the refusal of the application: Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Best (1993) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-210 (failure to serve medical reports within the time required by the rules).
Legislation cited in [s 66.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Aid Commission Act 1979 s 56.

There is no automatic right to an adjournment for the purpose of obtaining legal representation — although it would ordinarily be proper to accede to an adjournment application for that purpose if the applicant has not been dilatory or otherwise in default: Robinson v R [1985] AC 956 ; McColl v Lehmann [1987] VR 503 at 506 ; Duo v Osborne [1992] 1 WLR 611 ; Blazevski v Judges of the District Court of New South Wales (1992) 29 ALD 197 (request to adjourn proceedings to a date convenient to counsel and agreed to by prosecutor); Dietrich v R (1992) 177 CLR 292; 109 ALR 385; BC9202663 ; Galos Hired v R [1944] AC 149 ; Kingsway Group Ltd v Belramoul [2009] NSWSC 345; BC200903445 at [11] (further adjournment refused — defendants had fair opportunity to overcome difficulties with legal representation). (Although mere optimism that further time will either secure legal representation: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 1081; BC200108029 (plaintiff unable to provide security); or reveal a more substantial basis for the claim or defence, cannot sustain an application for adjournment: EG & H Nominees Pty Ltd v General Mutual Insurance Co Ltd (in liq) (1976) 50 ALJR 460 (winding up proceedings), cf in bankruptcy, Field v Commercial Banking Co of Sydney Ltd (1978) 22 ALR 403; 37 FLR 341 .) However where a party has unsuccessfully applied for legal aid and has appealed, or proposes to appeal, under s 56 of the Legal Aid Commission Act 1979, and the court is satisfied that the appeal is bona fide, then the court is required to grant an adjournment unless special circumstances prevent it from doing so: Friends of the Glenreagh Dorrigo Line Inc v Jones (NSWCA, CA 40323 of 1991, Gleeson CJ, Kirby and Mahoney JJA, 30 March 1994, unreported, BC9402362). An adjournment may be appropriate where there is material indicating that an appeal had been made to the Legal Aid Review Committee and the application for Legal Aid is in the process of being redetermined notwithstanding that there is some doubt as to whether the pre-conditions in s 56 have been satisfied: Liristis v Gadelrabb [2012] NSWCA 137; BC201203077 at [8]–[13] per Tobias JA (determination of applicant’s Legal Aid appeal allowed to run its course).

Particular difficulties in the exercise of the discretion arise where a previously unrepresented party applies for an adjournment to obtain legal representation or advice as a result of an inability to understand or satisfy the procedural or substantive requirements that apply to the presentation of their case. While on the one hand the court is obliged to recognise and seek to overcome the difficulties faced by an unrepresented litigant, it must also avoid creating an disadvantage or appearance of unfairness to the represented party. Titan v Babic (1994) 49 FCR 546 at 554–5; 126 ALR 455 ; Re Hunter; Ex parte Webb (Fed C of A, Sheppard J, 19 July 1996, unreported, BC9604062); Jarrett v Westpac Banking Corp [1999] FCA 425; BC9901826 ; Azar v Berry Kitchens Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 678; BC200104769 .

It will ordinarily be proper to accede to an application which only involves a very short adjournment. Thus, in Carryer v Kelly [1969] 2 NSWR 769; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 566 , a judge was held to be in error in not agreeing to an adjournment from 12.30 pm to 2 pm for counsel to appear where there had been confusion in the lists, see also Lynn v Ringwood [1964] NSWR 199 . In Petrovic v Taara Form Work (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1982) 62 FLR 451 , the Full Court said that it was unsatisfactory to refuse a plaintiff an adjournment late Friday afternoon until Monday morning to call a witness who was absent on Friday because her mother had died that day where opposition appeared to be influenced by the state of the list and counsel's convenience.

The unavailability of material witnesses is usually a sufficient ground for an adjournment: Ord v Ord [1923] 2 KB 432 at 439 (ill witness); R v Foster; Ex parte Isaacs [1941] VLR 77; Dick v Piller [1943] 1 KB 497 (witness an expectant mother approaching confinement); Grimshaw v Dunbar [1953] 1 QB 408 ; Hayman v Rowlands [1957] 1 All ER 321 ; Biro v Lloyd [1964–5] NSWR 1059 at 1062; Vasiljev v Public Trustee [1974] 2 NSWLR 497 ; Myers v Myers [1969] WAR 19 ; Petrovic v Taara Form Work (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1982) 62 FLR 451 (expert witness attending mother’s funeral, short adjournment wrongly refused at trial). As to the appropriate order for costs in such cases see Ord v Ord , above; Lydall v Martinson (1877) 5 Ch D 780 ; Lucas v Meagher (1876) 13 WN (NSW) 67; cf Earp Woodcock Beveridge & Co Ltd v Gordon (1927) 44 WN (NSW) 123. Clearly, mere matters of witness' or parties' convenience, as distinct from a physical inability to attend, are highly unlikely to justify an adjournment: Bloch v Bloch (1981) 180 CLR 390; 37 ALR 55; 55 ALJR 701; BC8100113 . For a case where an adjournment was refused see R v Public Service Board of Victoria; Ex parte McDonald [1948] VLR 310 .

level.toc-caption: [s 66.45] Appeal against refusal of application for adjournment

heading.title: Appeal against refusal of application for adjournment

p.text: Adjournment decisions involve the exercise of a procedural discretion by a trial judge. An appeal from a decision to refuse an adjournment (practical considerations tend to militate against the likelihood of an appeal against a decision to grant an adjournment) attracts the ordinary appellate disinclination to interfere with the exercise of such a discretionary power: see [SCA s 101.60] . An appellant must establish that the adjournment refusal resulted in injustice, either because it was based on a wrong principle, an irrelevant consideration, inadequate regard to relevant considerations or because of its practical consequences for the proper resolution of the proceedings: Squire v Rogers (1979) 27 ALR 330 at 337–8; 39 FLR 106 per Deane J citing Sackville-West v A-G (1910) 128 LT 265 ; Conroy v Conroy (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 680 ; Maxwell v Keun [1928] 1 KB 645; [1927] All ER Rep 335 ; see also Bloch v Bloch (1981) 180 CLR 390 at 395; 37 ALR 55; BC8100113 .
Examples of successful appeals against the refusal of an adjournment include:

applications to obtain critical evidence: Thornberry v R (1995) 69 ALJR 777 (adjournment sought to obtain alibi evidence); Petrovic v Taara Form Work (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1982) 62 FLR 451 ; Vasiljev v Public Trustee [1974] 2 NSWLR 497 (application to obtain instructions from non English speaking overseas resident); and

applications for the purpose of obtaining legal representation: Blazevski v Judges of the District Court of New South Wales (1992) 29 ALD 197 (successful appeal against failure to grant short adjournment to secure legal representation); Collier Garland (Properties) Pty Ltd v Northern Transport Co Pty Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 1414 (similar application); Carryer v Kelly [1969] 2 NSWR 769; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 566 (counsel temporarily engaged in another court).

applications where there is a material risk of other proceedings involving the need to determine related issues, and the likelihood of adjournment being required for other reasons in any event: Dubois v R & V Bergin Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 309; BC201107715 per Young JA (Giles JA agreeing) (proceedings involving separate motor vehicle accidents — requirement to obtain impairment certificate as a precondition to the award of damages).
Examples of unsuccessful appeals against the refusal of an adjournment include:
an application to permit a party to attend the hearing: Bloch v Bloch (1981) 180 CLR 390 at 395; 37 ALR 55; BC8100113 (party employed overseas — previous adjournments — no genuine attempt to attend);
an application to obtain an interpreter: Adamopoulos v Olympic Airways SA (1991) 25 NSWLR 75 (unsuccessful application to adjourn to secure an interpreter);

an application to obtain expert evidence: Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Best (1993) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-210 (unsuccessful appeal — medical expert injured after waiting to give evidence — evidence not material to liability issues);

applications for the purpose of obtaining legal representation: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625; BC9303602 (inadequate evidence of the unavailability of legal representation); Dawson (t/as Goodvibes Yachts) v DCT (1984) 56 ALR 367; 71 FLR 364 at 374 (inability to pay — legal representatives ceasing to act); and
an application anticipating legislative changes: Sydney City Council v Ke-Su Investments Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 246 .

level.toc-caption: [s 66.50] Appeal against the grant of an adjournment

heading.title: Appeal against the grant of an adjournment

p.text: As in the case of appeal against the refusal of an adjournment an appellate court will not readily interfere with the exercise of the discretion where an adjournment application has been granted in the court below: Pfitzner v Pfitzner (1988) 62 ALJR 323 ; Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd v Australian Meat Industry Employees’ Union (1986) 12 FCR 10 . Nevertheless where the grant of the adjournment has been based upon a wrong principle or results in serious injustice an appeal may be allowed: Ahern v DCT (Qld) (1987) 76 ALR 137 ; Deputy Cmr of Taxation v Swain (1988) 81 ALR 12 (concurrent proceedings in the Federal and Family Courts).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 67] s 67 Stay of proceedings (cf Act No 9 1973, section 156)

leg:heading.title: Stay of proceedings (cf Act No 9 1973, section 156)

p.text: Subject to rules of court, the court may at any time and from time to time, by order, stay any proceedings before it, either permanently or until a specified day.

level.toc-caption: [s 67.5] Nature and extent of the power to stay proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 67.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 13.4, r 23.9.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 138(1), ss 61(1), 61(3), s 61(3)(a), 65.

heading.title: Nature and extent of the power to stay proceedings

p.text: Section 67 does not identify any particular criteria for the exercise of the power to stay proceedings. At least in the Supreme Court, it may be understood to cover a Variety of circumstances in which the Court’s inherent jurisdiction to prevent abuse of its process may be invoked: New South Wales v Plaintiff A [2012] NSWCA 248; BC201206211 at [15] and see [s 67.15] . In other courts the power would certainly extend to include matters within their “incidental” jurisdiction: see [s 68.20] .
A significant feature of the CPA and UCPR is the power to dismiss proceedings as a sanction for non-compliance. The dismissal power can be exercised where:
proceedings are irregular (eg, UCPR r 13.4 — power to dismiss vexatious or abusive proceedings)
parties have not complied with the requirements of the Rules (eg, UCPR r 23.9 — power to dismiss proceedings for non-compliance with requirements for medical examinations or inspection of property)

Typically these sanction powers do not explicitly grant a power to stay proceedings. However, there is clearly an incidental power to stay proceedings as a means of securing compliance with directions: see Edmeades v Thames Board Mills Ltd [1969] 2 QB 67; [1969] 2 All ER 127; [1969] 2 WLR 668; [1969] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 221 (failure to submit to medical examination). The preservation of such a power is implicit in CPA ss 61(1) , 61(3) and 65 . Similarly there is also an incidental power to stay execution of judgments and that power is continued by the court’s ample powers to give directions in relation to the enforcement of its judgments: see CPA s 138(1) .
Legislation cited in [s 67.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56, 59, ss 64, 65, s 86(2).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 12.10, rr 12.4, r 13.2, r 24.4(4), r 42.21.

The provisions of ss 64 and 65 , read in the light of ss 56 and 59 of the CPA (the “overriding purpose” and “elimination of delay” provisions) display a preference that, so far as appropriate, the stay power should only be exercised for finite periods. A corollary of that preference is the general proposition that the dismissal power should be exercised where the irregularity or non-compliance is such as to justify excluding the matter entirely from proceeding to determination. Despite that preference, the present section does recognise the court’s power to stay proceedings for indefinite periods. In part that recognition is required by other provisions of the CPA and the UCPR. In particular, there are express powers to stay proceedings until costs or expenses are paid: see eg, rr 12.4 , 12.10 (discontinued proceedings or proceedings dismissed for lack of progress).

There is power to stay proceedings until the determination of a cross-claim: r 13.2 . There is power to stay proceedings for failure to pay examination expenses: r 24.4(4) . Similarly security for costs may be ordered on terms that the proceedings are stayed until security has been provided: see r 42.21 of the UCPR. And there is even authority for the view that, at least in an exceptional case, the stay power conferred by the present section could be exercised, in conjunction with s 86(2) , to order a stay of proceedings, subject to the provision of security for costs: Phillips Electronics Australia Pty Ltd v Matthews (2002) 54 NSWLR 598; [2002] NSWCA 157; BC200202749 ; Byrnes v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 251; BC200602077 .

level.toc-caption: [s 67.15] Inherent jurisdiction to stay or strike out — Supreme Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 67.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Appeal Act 1912 s 5F.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 Div 2.

heading.title: Inherent jurisdiction to stay or strike out — Supreme Court

p.text: Apart from any specific statutory provision the Supreme Court possesses an inherent jurisdiction (sometimes described as an inherent power) to stay proceedings which are an abuse of process: Jago v District Court of New South Wales (1989) 168 CLR 23; 87 ALR 577; BC8902707 ; Clyne v New South Wales Bar Assn (1960) 104 CLR 186 at 201; [1960] ALR 574; BC6000600 ; Barton v R (1980) 147 CLR 75 at 96, 107, 116; 32 ALR 449 ; Berger v Raymond Sun Ltd [1984] 1 WLR 625 (unduly prolonging a trial). The jurisdiction extends to the exercise of power to stay either criminal or civil proceedings where such an order is necessary to prevent their conduct giving rise to injustice: Batistatos v RTA of NSW (2006) 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 (stay of long delayed civil proceedings); Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254 at 1301; [1964] 2 WLR 1145 (subsequent criminal proceedings involving related offences); Herron v McGregor (1986) 6 NSWLR 246 at 251 (stay of long delayed disciplinary proceedings against medical practitioners); Clayton v Ralphs (1987) 45 SASR 347 at 363; Cooke v Purcell (1988) 14 NSWLR 51 at 63, 77 (long delayed criminal proceedings); Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 ; Metropolitan Bank Ltd v Pooley (1885) 10 App Cas 210 at 214; [1881–5] All ER Rep 949 ; Mills v Cooper [1967] 2 QB 459 at 467; [1967] 2 All ER 100 (criminal proceedings after prior acquittal on a similar charge — no stay).

The Supreme Court has power to stay proceedings in courts over which the court exercises supervisory jurisdiction: Re Austin; Ex parte Farren (1960) 77 WN (NSW) 743 at 744–5 ; John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd v McRae (1955) 93 CLR 351 at 363; [1955] ALR 265 ; R v Grassby (1989) 15 NSWLR 109 at 116; Watson v A-G (NSW) (1987) 8 NSWLR 685 at 697; 28 A Crim R 332 (criminal proceedings in the District Court). Similarly, the Supreme Court may grant a stay in respect of proceedings before inferior disciplinary tribunals where there has been undue delay: Herron v McGregor (1986) 6 NSWLR 246 (medical disciplinary tribunal proceedings); Gill v Walton (1991) 25 NSWLR 190 ; Walton v Gardiner (1993) 177 CLR 378; 112 ALR 289; BC9303612 . However where a stay application has been refused by an inferior tribunal and there is a right of appeal against that refusal (for example, s 5F of the Criminal Appeal Act 1912 in relation to proceedings on indictment and proceedings under Ch 3, Pt 2, Div 2 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986) the exercise of the Supreme Court’s supervisory jurisdiction will ordinarily be withheld in favour of the exercise of the right of appeal.
Legislation cited in [s 67.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 13.4, 14.28.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 84.

The powers referred to in the preceding note are principally treated as falling with the inherent jurisdiction of the Supreme Court. But there is an ill defined distinction between the “inherent jurisdiction” of the Supreme Court and the “incidental powers” that any court has to control, and to ensure the proper and fair use of, its jurisdiction: see [SCA s 23.15]-[SCA s 23.25] and Batistatos v RTA of NSW (2006) 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 at [121]–[136] . The exercise of a power to stay proceedings may be justified as falling within a court’s incidental powers as a necessary adjunct to the effective exercise of its jurisdiction. In that regard there is an obvious analogy between the power to adjourn and the power to stay, where the application is based on the unavailability of a witness or party: see [s 66.40] and compare Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [79] (no power to grant a permanent stay where defendant’s disabling medical condition attributable to wholly extraneous events). Similarly, a court with jurisdiction in relation to corporate winding up (the Supreme Court) may restrain a creditor from commencing proceedings to wind up a company in reliance on non-compliance with a disputed statutory demand: CVC Investments Pty Ltd v P & T Aviation Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 295 . See also Besant v Wood (1879) 12 Ch D 605 and Hart v Hart (1881) 18 Ch D 670 at 680 ; Cercle Restaurant Castiglione Co v Lavery (1881) 18 Ch D 555 ; Bryanston Finance Ltd v De Vries (No 2) [1976] Ch 63; [1976] 1 All ER 25 ; Club Marconi of Bossley Park v Rennat Constructions Pty Ltd (1980) 4 ACLR 883 ; L and D Audio Acoustics Pty Ltd v Pioneer Electronics Aust Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 180 ; Re Julius Harper Ltd; Ex parte Winkler and Co (Hong Kong) Ltd [1983] NZLR 215 ; Anglian Sales Ltd v South Pacific Manufacturing Co Ltd [1984] 2 NZLR 249. These examples are merely illustrations of the more general principle that any court has the power to prevent the misuse of its procedure. Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254 at 1301; [1964] 2 WLR 1145 ; Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd (1987) 162 CLR 612 at 623–4; 71 ALR 457; BC8701781 . That power may be exercised to stay or dismiss any proceedings that would be manifestly unfair: Batistatos v RTA of NSW [2006] 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 at [5]–[6] and [9]–[12] ; see further [14.28.5] .

The general principle is acknowledged in the present section, which explicitly permits any Civil Procedure Act court to stay any proceedings in the court. That power is also complemented by the power, conferred by rr 13.4 and 14.28 , to dismiss proceedings and strike out pleadings on various specific grounds, including abuse of process (see [14.28.5] ). That power has a particular additional aspect where a litigant has repeatedly commenced unwarranted and vexatious proceedings.

In relation to particular proceedings, any court seized of the proceedings may deal with them under either the present section or the rules referred to above. The commencement of any further proceedings by the particular litigant may be restrained either under the inherent power of the Supreme Court: see, eg, Grepe v Loam (1887) 37 Ch D 168 ; Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia v Inglis (1974) 131 CLR 311; 3 ALR 19; BC7400019 , or pursuant to s 84 of the Supreme Court Act 1970. Further examples of the circumstances in which proceedings may be stayed under the jurisdiction conferred by the present section are discussed in the following notes.
Legislation cited in [s 67.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 87.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128.

The question of a stay based upon pending or anticipated criminal proceedings now falls to be considered simply under the court’s general discretion. The burden is upon the applicant for the stay (generally the defendant in the civil proceedings) to show that it is just and convenient that the respondent plaintiff's ordinary right to have the proceedings proceed to hearing in the ordinary way should be deferred because of potential injustice in relation to the defence of the criminal proceedings: Caesar v Sommer [1980] 2 NSWLR 929 per Roden J; Jefferson Ltd v Bhetcha [1979] 2 All ER 1108; [1979] 1 WLR 898 ; Re Saltergate Insurance Co Ltd (in liq) and the Companies Act (1980) 4 ACLR 733 ; McMahon v Gould (1982) 7 ACLR 202; 1 ACLC 98 ; Odes v Hamilton (1987) 11 NSWLR 138 (concurrent criminal proceedings and a public examination under s 541 of the Companies Code 1981); Edelsten v Richmond (1987) 11 NSWLR 51 . What is commonly involved is a balancing exercise between the civil litigant's interests against the other party's right to silence in the criminal proceedings. That balance is potentially affected by the certificate procedures available under both s 87 of the CPA and s 128 of the Evidence Act 1995. It may also be assisted by other procedural directions without the need for an adjournment: Fotis v Favret (NSWSC, Santow J, No 4431/95, 8 May 1996, unreported, BC9601965). A defendant cannot rely on pending criminal proceedings against a plaintiff as grounds for a stay: Davidson v Sydney County Council Employees’ Credit Union [1979] 1 NSWLR 41 . Where civil proceedings have been commenced the Supreme Court also has jurisdiction to restrain the continuance of subsequent criminal proceedings which raise the same issue as that which falls to be decided in the civil proceedings: Thames Launches Ltd v Trinity House Corp [1961] Ch 197 ; Royal Bank of Scotland Ltd v Citrusdal Investments Ltd [1971] 1 WLR 1469 .

(As an alternative to granting a stay, the court may give directions designed to ensure that the hearing of the civil proceedings occurs after the determination of the criminal proceedings: Silbermann v CGU Insurance Ltd (2003) 48 ACSR 231; [2003] NSWSC 1127; BC200307325 ).
